author: The Australian
title: Groupon begins life as a genuine online player
text:
As part of the transformation Groupon’s Australian website and app will receive a substantial facelift, with Groupon Australia CEO Alistair Venn saying that it’s the logical next step for the company.
It wasn’t that long ago that the Australian market boasted as many as 80 group-buying sites but in five years the allure of coupons and group bargains has waned appreciably.
Mr Venn says that daily deals have been on the way out for some time and while it made a lot of sense in the early days they have to some extent outlived their usefulness.
“For the customers it was something new and exciting, it helped them save money and find out new things to do in their cities,” he said.
“As for the merchants it helped them acquire customers and grow revenue but it was only for a very small number of them at any given time.”
According to Mr Venn, while customers liked the bargains and merchants welcomed the extra business the process was far from perfect.
“It didn’t save customer time; it wasn’t personalised or customised in any way,” he said.
Meanwhile, merchants were also left dissatisfied by the process.
“The extra customers were great but servicing the sudden flow was difficult. They wanted a lot more insight into the types of customer that they could target and engage with on a more ongoing basis.”
Addressing these needs has been a big driver of the change flowing through Groupon, with the revamped website just the “tip of the iceberg,” according to Mr Venn.
The new website is designed to give Groupon customers greater functionality in sorting and searching of the myriad deals on offer.
There’s also a personalisation and curation aspect. The printed voucher has also been retired in favour of a paperless redemption option and a new app functionality lets users view all deals within their proximity.
